definition[0]: to form a particular amount or part of something
example[0]: Afro-Americans account for 12% of the US population.
definition[1]: to be the reason why something happens
example[1]: Recent pressure at work may account for his behavior.
definition[2]: to give a satisfactory explanation of why something has happened or why you did something
example[2]: Can you account for your movements on that night?
definition[3]: to say where all the members of a group of people or things are, especially because you are worried that some of them may be lost
example[3]: Three days after the earthquake, more than 150 people had still to be accounted for.
definition[4]: to be a particular amount or part of something
example[4]: Own-label products now account for more than 20% of sales in some European supermarkets.
definition[5]: to show something in a companyâ€™s accounts in a particular way
example[5]: In financial statements, the bonds should be accounted for as debt.
